The small size of the historic community of dinosaur specialists made it vulnerable to a powerful individual pushing for his preferred reconstruction. But science is self-correcting, and it ultimately worked the way it was supposed to.

So now it's the 1970s, and people have been looking at round-headed Apatosaurus for a couple generations. Paleontologist John McIntosh finds the Dinosaur Nat'l Monument skull in the Carnegie collections, and untangles the whole story. Mounted skeletons are reheaded within the decade‚Äîhooray!

And so, through a combination of bullying and inertia, it becomes accepted that the sculpted model skull at AMNH must be right, and that a Camarasaurus-shaped head is a suitable substitute when putting an Apatosaurus/Brontosaurus on display.
